title: My Honest Take on Pineapple Tallow Balm (And Why My Expensive Cream Sucks)
body:
Okay so. My hands were a disaster last month. Like, cracking at the knuckles, red, the whole thing. It was cold, my apartment heater makes the air feel like sandpaper, you know how it is. I was using this fancy cream I got at the mall, the blue jar one from Kiehl’s. The Ultimate Strength Hand Salve. It was like forty bucks. And it did nothing. Actually no, it did something. It made my hands feel greasy for an hour and then they’d be just as dry and tight and awful. I’d put it on before bed and wake up feeling like I’d dipped my hands in flour. It was so frustrating. I was just sitting there one night, it was probably a Tuesday, looking at my sad knuckles and thinking about how much money I’d wasted on that blue jar. And my neck hurt from the chair. Anyway.

That’s when I remembered this weird thing I’d seen online. Beef tallow. For your skin. I know, it sounds insane. Like, cooking fat? On your face? On your hands? I thought it was some crunchy hippie thing that would smell like a barn. But I was desperate. And I kept seeing people talk about how it actually works. So I went looking. Found this little Etsy shop that makes whipped tallow balms. And they had a pineapple one. Pineapple! That sounded way less intimidating than “unscented beef fat.” So I ordered it. The Whipped Tallow Balm in Pineapple. I figured if I was gonna smear cow fat on myself, at least it could smell like vacation.

## How I Ended Up Using Beef Fat on My Face

It showed up in a little jar. Cute packaging, honestly. I opened it and poked it. The texture was weird. Not bad weird. It’s like… thick but soft? You scoop a little and it melts as soon as you start rubbing it. It doesn’t feel greasy like that Kiehl’s stuff did. It just sort of… goes away. Into your skin. The smell is not like a pineapple candy, thank god. It’s more like… you cut open a real pineapple. That tropical, sweet-but-a-little-tangy smell. It’s cheerful. It doesn’t smell like beef at all, which was my biggest fear. It just smells like summer. Which was nice in the dead of winter, with my sad hands.

So I tried it. On my wrecked knuckles first. I put a tiny bit on before bed, fully expecting to hate it. I woke up and my hands were… fine. Just fine. Not cracked. Not tight. Not greasy. Just normal skin. I was shocked. I kept using it. Every night. After a week, my hands were actually soft. Not “lotion soft” that lasts five minutes. Actually, genuinely, my-hands-don’t-hurt-anymore soft. I started putting it on my elbows too, because why not. They’re always rough. Same thing. It just… fixed them. I don’t know how else to say it.

Then I got brave. My face gets dry patches in winter, especially around my nose. I’ve tried everything. La Mer samples (a joke), CeraVe (fine but not great), some French pharmacy thing my friend swore by. All either did nothing or made me break out. So one night, I put the tiniest dab of this pineapple tallow balm on my dry patches. I was prepared for a zit explosion. But the next morning, the patches were gone. Gone! And no new zits. So I kept doing it. Now I use it as my night moisturizer maybe twice a week. My skin has never been happier. Or more confused, probably.

## Why This Tallow Stuff Works When My Expensive Creams Didn't

I looked it up because I was so confused. How can beef fat be better than science-y stuff in a lab? Turns out it’s kind of simple. This tallow balm is made from grass-fed beef suet, whipped up into this creamy texture. They make it in France, apparently. And the reason it works so well is that it’s really similar to the oils our own skin makes. Our sebum. So our skin recognizes it. It absorbs deep instead of sitting on top like a silicone-y film. That’s why that Kiehl’s salve felt so greasy—it was just coating me, not actually helping. This tallow balm gets in there and does the work.

It’s the difference between putting a band-aid on a cut and your body actually healing it. Most commercial moisturizers are the band-aid. They have a ton of ingredients, some good, some just there to make it feel nice going on. But they don’t give your skin what it actually needs to repair itself. This tallow balm is basically just one ingredient: food for your skin. It’s a natural moisturizer in the most literal sense. It’s wild to me that I spent years and so much money on “natural vs commercial skincare” when the answer was this simple, weird thing.

I got mine from this Etsy shop, just a small maker. It feels good to use something that isn’t made in a huge factory, you know? It feels personal. And it works. That’s the main thing.

## My Skin After a Few Weeks of This Pineapple Stuff

So what’s different? It’s not a miracle. I didn’t turn into a glowing goddess. But my skin is just… calm. My hands are normal. My elbows aren’t sandpaper. The dry patches on my face are history. It’s like my skin finally has what it needs, so it stopped freaking out. It’s resilient now. I can wash my hands without immediately needing cream. That’s a big deal for me in winter.

The best part is how simple it is. I have this one little jar. I use it on my hands, my elbows, my face, even on a cuticle that’s acting up. I don’t need five different products. It’s just this one thing that fixes a bunch of problems. I’m probably gonna order another jar soon because I don’t want to run out. I even told my mom about it, and she’s super skeptical about everything. She hasn’t tried it yet but I’m working on her.

Would I call it the best natural moisturizer? For me, right now, yeah. Because it actually does the job. It’s not marketing. It’s not a fancy smell in pretty packaging. It’s a functional thing that works. And it smells like pineapple, which is a nice bonus. It makes the whole experience feel less clinical and more like a little treat. A little tropical escape in a jar when it’s freezing outside.

## Quick Questions I Get Asked

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
Yeah, surprisingly. I was super skeptical. But because it mimics our skin’s own oils, it absorbs really well and doesn’t just clog stuff up. It’s been great for my dry spots. If you have super oily or acne-prone skin, maybe patch test first, but for my dry winter skin, it’s perfect.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
Not in my experience. It’s non-comedogenic, which means it shouldn’t. It sinks in instead of sitting on top of your skin. That greasy feeling is usually from pore-clogging ingredients, and this doesn’t have that feeling at all. It just disappears.

**What does the pineapple tallow balm smell like?**
Like a real pineapple, not candy. It’s sweet and tropical and a little bright. It’s not overpowering. It just smells nice and cheerful. Definitely no beef smell. At all.

So yeah. That’s my tallow balm review. I went from being grossed out by the idea to being a total convert. My expensive creams are sitting in a drawer, and I’m just using this little jar of whipped beef fat that smells like fruit. Life is weird. Anyway, if your skin is being difficult with regular stuff, this might be worth a shot. It was for me.
